newsitem.title: USA: DC bond documents say SEC muni probe unwarranted.
newsitem.headline: DC bond documents say SEC muni probe unwarranted.

text.p: The District of Columbia told investors in a recent general obligation bond offering that an SEC probe launched in February 1995 of city bonds continues despite being groundless.

"The District does not believe that it violated the federal securities laws in connection with such offerings," the city said in the preliminary Official Statement for the $168.87 million of GO bonds sold October 3.
Nevertheless, the investigation launched February 9, 1995 "is ongoing," the District said in the document.

"The District cannot, at this time, predict what action, if any, the SEC will take as a result of the investigation or what impact, if any, the investigation may have on the District or its securities," the POS says.

Daniel Rezneck, general counsel for District's five-member control board told D.C. lawyers October 9 that the SEC's probe continues and probably has been expanded to cover city financial statements for fiscal year 1995.
"The District sold a large amount of bonds in" late 1994, Rezneck said. "The result was an SEC investigation of the District which is still ongoing."

Rezneck added that D.C. auditor KPMG Peat Marwick in January highlighted deficiencies in D.C.'s financial statements for FY 1995. Thos recent findings are "undoubtedly part of SEC's investigation," Rezneck said.
D.C.'s lawyer Gerald Laporte, an attorney with the lawfirm Patton Boggs, said he had no comment on the investigation.
Washington sources say SEC is examining the quality of D.C.'s disclosure in the December 1994 notes sale, among other matters.

When the 1994 notes were sold through a syndicate led by Prudential Securities Inc. bond documents put D.C.'s budget deficit at $492 million. Six weeks later, however, city officials estimated it at roughly $722 million.
Rezneck told lawyers at the October 9 D.C. bar meeting that SEC probably would not be investigating the city as enthusiastically if D.C. were not at its doorstep.
